title: Using Mendelian randomization to investigate a possible causal relationship between adiposity and increased bone mineral density at different skeletal sites in children
author: Kemp
author_address: University of Queensland Diamantina Institute, Level 5 Translational Research Institute, Woolloongabba, Brisbane 4102, QLD, Australia
hypothesis: Effect of adiposity on bone mineral density
rationale: Lean mass is positively associated with bone mineral density (BMD). However, the relationship between adiposity and BMD is more controversial. In particu- lar, it is unclear if the observational association between the two reflects a causal effect of fat mass on BMD.
outcome_definition: Dual-energy X-ray absoptiometry (DXA) measures of BMD were derived for this region of interest
exposure_n_difference_reason: One-sample where they got exposure SNPs from external GWAS
exposure_covariates_model: Sex and age were included as covariates in order to generate estimates from the IV analyses that were comparable to those from the observational regressions
exposure_genotyping_dataset: Illumina HumanHap550 quad genome-wide SNP genotyping platform
exposure_independence: r²  values for SNPs given in supplementary tables
exposure_HWE: Only SNPs that passed an exact test of Hardy– Weinberg equilibrium (P > 5 x10-7) were considered for analysis
limitations_overall: Findings would benefit from replication in a larger sample of individuals as well as utilizing SNPs that are specific (and strongly associated with) lean or fat mass.
limitations_pleiotropy: Employed two statistical procedures to mitigate concerns due to horizontal pleiotropy: MR Egger regression and multivariable MR.
limitations_population_stratification: EIGENSTRAT analysis revealed no additional obvious population stratification

title: Causal inference of the effect of adiposity on bone mineral density in adults
author: Warodomwichit
author_address: Department of Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, Ramathibodi Hospital, Mahidol University, Bangkok 10400, Thailand
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index, body fat mass, and body fat percentage on bone mineral density
rationale: The causal effect of adipose tissue on bone mass and the direction of its net influence have not been directly assessed in adult humans.
limitations_overall: Although causality is sug- gested by these analyses, the underlying mechanism(s) still require further investigation
limitations_pleiotropy: It is therefore unclear whether adiposity directly leads to high bone mass or is simply related to BMD because of the confounding effect of body size and weight.
